body:
<!--
**PLEASE READ THIS FIRST:**
- Do not use the bug and feature tracker for support requests. Use the `cython-users` mailing list instead.
- Did you search for similar issues already? Please do, it helps to save us precious time that we otherwise could not invest into development.
- Did you try the latest master branch or pre-release? It might already have what you want to report. Also see the [Changelog](https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/master/CHANGES.rst) regarding recent changes.
-->

**Describe the bug**
String literals with underscores (e.g. "1_2_3") are backported to work on older Python versions. However, this only works when the type is known to be a string/bytes type. It also depends on the output type that's being coerced to.

**To Reproduce**
Code to reproduce the behaviour:
```cython
passthrough = lambda x: x

def f():
    float("1_2_3")  # OK, goes through __Pyx_PyString_AsDouble
    float(passthrough("1_2_3"))  # OK, goes through __Pyx_PyObject_AsDouble
    [float("1_2_3")]  # OK, goes through __Pyx_PyString_AsDouble
    [float(passthrough("1_2_3"))]  # FAIL - goes through __Pyx_PyNumber_Float (which just calls "float" constructor)
```

**Expected behavior**
Not 100% sure what the expected behaviour should be. Probably something consistent though

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Linux
 - Python version 2.7 (and I think older 3.x versions too)
 - Cython version: master

**Additional context**
This is the reason that the builtin_float test is currently failing. On that `fix_underscores` returns a Python object of unknown type.
title: [BUG] String literal to float parsing is different when the type is known
